title: Why I Teach Soroban, Not Just "Math" – A Teacher's Perspective
description: After 10 years teaching math, I discovered soroban changed everything. Here's what makes it different from traditional math instruction.

content.intro: I've taught elementary math for a decade. Worksheets, textbooks, manipulatives – I've used it all. When I discovered soroban, I realized I'd been missing something fundamental about how kids learn numbers.

items: Procedures ("here's how to add with carrying")
Multiple strategies ("you can count up, count back, make tens...")

sections.text: These aren't wrong, but they often miss something: kids don't develop a FEEL for numbers. They follow rules without intuition.

items: **One consistent method:** Not "pick your strategy" – one reliable approach
**Physical to mental:** Concrete manipulation → mental visualization
**Pattern recognition:** Numbers become images, not symbols
**Speed through automaticity:** Fluency, not just accuracy

sections.text: The first time I saw a soroban student calculate faster than I could – mentally – I knew I had to understand this method.
I started recommending soroban for students who:

items: Had math anxiety from "getting it wrong"
Were advanced and bored with grade-level work

sections.text: The results surprised me. Kids who were "bad at math" excelled at soroban. Kids who were bored found a new challenge.
No. And I don't use it that way. Soroban supplements school math by building:

items: Number sense that helps with ALL math

sections.text: Students still learn fractions, geometry, word problems separately. But their calculation foundation is stronger.
Soroban won't teach your child everything in math. It will make everything in math easier because they'll understand numbers deeply.

faq.question: Should soroban replace homework help?
faq.answer: No. Help with homework as needed. Soroban is separate practice that builds foundational skills over time.

faq.question: Will soroban conflict with how I teach?
faq.answer: Rarely. Different methods coexist. Students know "this is my soroban way, this is my school way" – like speaking two languages.

faq.question: At what grade level do you recommend starting?
faq.answer: Kindergarten to 3rd grade is ideal for starting. Later is fine too, but earlier gives more compounding time.

cta.text: Give your child the number sense that makes all math easier.
